No notable stories

content:
AUSTRALIA

Link Administration (LNK AT) – Co. is said to plan to offer a bid of over AUD 1bln for PEXA. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) – Co. says current copper demand is above trend on China. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT) – Co. has widened its search from brokers to sell its petrol business through a proposed USD 2bln-odd float. (AFR)

Shopping Centres Australasia Property (SCP AT) – Co. announced the acquisition of AUD 573mln convenience-based portfolio. (Newswires)

Perpetual (PPT AS) – Co. names Chris Green as CFO effective 15th October this year. (Newswires)

Paringa Resources (PNL AS) – Co. announced a coal sale agreement with Ohia Valley Electric and Indiana-Kentucky electric. The agreement is for coal sales equal to 650k tons from 2019 to 2020. (Newswires)

Vicinity Centres (VCX AS) – Co. announces the sale of 11 centres valued at AUD 631mln. Co. also affirms FY19 FFO guidance. (Newswires)

Boss Resources (BOE AS) – Co. is to sell its interest in projects to joint venture partner Teranga Gold Australia. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

- Australia has warned China over “aggressive tactics” after a US warship was challenged by a Chinese destroyer in the South China Sea. (The Australian)

COMMODITIES

WTI was little changed following a narrower than expected build for crude stocks at the API crude inventory release.

JAPAN

Shiseido (4911 JT) – Co. is said to boost marketing in Chinese and Asian markets in order to increase sale of namesake brand. Co. is discontinue Diciila skincare brand. (Nikkei)

Daiwa House Industry (1925 JT) – Co. is said to plan to invest JPY 30bln by the end of FY 2020 to build 80 megasolar plants in Japan. (Nikkei)

Subaru (7270 JT) – reported September US vehicle sales +3.5% Y/Y to 57k units. (Newswires)

Mazda Motor (7261 JT) - reported September US vehicle sales -17.4% Y/Y to 21.3k units. Separately, Co. is to launch full EV and rotary hybrid in 2020. (Newswires)

Suruga Bank (8358 JT) – Japan’s FSA is to order the Co, to halt some operations after a probe into lending practices; according to sources. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi (7211 JT) - reported September US vehicle sales -8.6% Y/Y at 7.7k units. (Newswires)

Lawson (2651 JT) – H1 operating speculated at JPY 34.5bln, around +10% Y/Y. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

- Tokyo Financial Exchange plans to expand trading to Hong Kong and Taiwan. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai (005380 KS) / Kia (000270 KS) – Co.’s debuted new models aimed at the European market. (Yonhap)

Kia (000270 KS) – Co.’s manufacturing costs are forecast to rise due to the USMCA deal. (Yonhap)

Samsung (005930 KS) – Co. plans to start the sale of the silver Galaxy Note 9 as early as this week. (Yonhap)

OTHER NEWS

- US Secretary of State Pompeo is to visit North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on Sunday. (FT)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

NEC Director Kudlow said US and China keep talking about trade, while the White House Advisory said China has not made a serious enough effort at appeasing the US. (Newswires)

UK

UK PM May said in the event of a no-deal Brexit, WTO tariffs would come into effect. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said we can expect to have a deal in time for Christmas and the UK must get a deal in November otherwise it’s too short on time for legislative time-frame. He added the UK cannot let the EU off the hook for cavalier rebuff of Chequers plan and there is no such thing as pure independence but UK is open to other deals. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said “as far as this government is concerned the Good Friday Agreement is not up for negotiation as part of Brexit”. (Newswires)

DUP Leader Foster said that there is no way they can accept different regulations in Northern Ireland and the rest of the country, not even as a backstop, he added DUP not bluffing on the backstop issue. (Newswires)


EU

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio confirmed the outlines of the 2019 budget, he reiterated the 2.4% deficit-GDP, he added Italy will go ahead with budget plan despite threats from EU and the budget will include EUR 10bln for "Citizen's Income". Di Maio said spending cuts and economic growth to ensure lower debt/GDP and he is not concerned about spread widening. (Newswires)

Italy's Deputy PM Salvini said that Italy is ready to ask for damages from President of the EU Commission Juncker and EU bureaucrats that are upsetting markets with their attacks on Italy. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte said the budget is aimed at accelerating the fall in the debt/GDP ratio over the coming three years and that they are beginning a dialogue with EU institutions on the budget, he added no decision has been made yet on the November summit.

Italian House Budget Committee President Borghi said Italy needs its own currency and that the reaction to his Euro comments show the currency isn't a shield against speculation. (Newswires)

EU Commissioner Dombrovskis says we need to apply the EU budget rules to Italy and Italy deficit plans go well beyond the rules. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) said a downward yield curve could signal that Fed policy is tight and policy is not that tight at the moment. He said trade tariffs could increase prices but US is not yet seeing effects from trade policy. Powell added gradual rates are meant to balance risks and there is a "remarkably positive outlook" on inflation and employment. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Dove, Non-voter) said he is happy with one more rate hike this year in December, base case is two next year. He is hopeful the Fed can raise rates to neutral without inverting the yield curve and the US economy is at or past full employment, while he said his view that US GDP will grow at 3% this year, 2.5% next year as fiscal stimulus fades. In regards to oil, he sees more upside risk to prices. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) sees spillover effects from EM as limited, he said there can be no influence of fiscal policy on monetary policy. (Newswires)

ECB's Rehn (Neutral) said Italy's budget poses serious concern. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Russian Energy Minister said he is in favour of Iran maintaining its position in the oil market and said for now OPEC and non-OPEC are operating on a case by case basis. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said oil prices seem a little high. (Newswires)

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (28 Sep) +0.907M vs. Exp. +2.000M (Prev. +2.903M) (Newswires)
US API Weekly Gasoline Stocks (28 Sep) -1.703mln (Exp. +1.300mln, Prev. +0.949mln)

US

US President Trump said there seems to be great support for the trade deal in Congress, while Senator Cornyn said the Senate may lack votes to approve the USMCA and the earliest vote could occur after November elections and could slip until next Congress. (Newswires)

Mexican Steel Chamber said if no solution can be found for the US steel and aluminium tariffs, Mexico should impose reciprocal measures on US steel imports. (Newswires)

New York State Taxation Department spokesperson said they are reviewing fraud allegations against US President Trump reported by the NYT. (CNBC)

MARKET RECAP

Intel (INTC) was one of the day’s biggest movers after giving constructive forward guidance. Micron Technologies (MU) another gainer, alongside Lam Research (LRCX) and Applied Materials (AMAT), helping edge up the Philadelphia SE semiconductor index. PG&E (PCG) and other utilities also benefitted from a risk off sentiment as defensive sectors lead on the day. AMD (AMD) moved downwards against the semiconductor industry. Delta Air Lines (DAL) fell on a disappointing earnings view which had a knock on effect on the wider airline industry. Guggenheim downgraded Edwards Lifesciences (EW) making it the S&P 500’s biggest underperformer at the time of writing. Some China based names were also other big losers with NetEase (NTES) and Baidu (BIDU) dragging down the Nasdaq.  

* SPX 0.00% at 2930, NDX -0.22% at 7628, DJI +0.47% at 26775 SECTORS: Energy +0.12%, Materials +0.45%, Industrials +0.19%, Cons Discretionary -1.43%, Cons Staples +0.62%, Healthcare -0.09%, Financials +0.04%, Tech -0.01%, Telecoms +0.11%, Utilities +1.28%.

Action in the Treasury complex was dictated by developments on the 2019 budget over in Italy which led to a steeper yield curve as the Italy/German spread widened above 300bps. The complex dipped later in the session after Comcast launched a 12-part dollar bond to fund its USD 27bln acquisition of Sky; subsequently some flattening was seen across the yield curve. Most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve were yields were higher by c.3bps. 2s10 s and 2s30s were narrower by c.2bps at settlement. US T-note futures (Z8) settles 4+ ticks higher at 118-26.

US MARKET WRAP – 2 October 2018: Fed’s Powell upbeat on US economy; Italy sparks risk-aversion

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, crude down, dollar up.

* REAR-VIEW: PM May to keep UK in EU’s customs union for goods after transition period, China to maintain talks with US, Fed's Powell upbeat on US economy, Fed’s Kaplan hopeful rate will rise without inverting yield curve, Italy to stick with 2.4% deficit.

* AHEAD: APIs AFMC//EU & UK Services PMI, US ADP National Employment, US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI, Fed's Barkin & Brainard and ECB's Mersch to speak.

 

* ITALY: European Commission Juncker during a speech late on Monday said Italy was moving away from the budget targets set by the EU, warning that if others were to get Italy’s treatment, it could trig the end of the Euro. Similarly, EU Commissioner Dombrovskis stressed once again the necessity to apply EU budget rules on Italy as the deficit plans go well beyond the rules, but noted the EU are open to dialogue with Italian authorities. In response to EU’s criticism, Deputy PM Di Maio said the unelected EU Commission pretends to lecture Italy's government declaring they will go ahead with budget plan despite threats from EU; he also added that spending cuts and economic growth are to ensure lower debt/GDP stressing they will not change the 2.4% debt/GDP target. He finally highlighted the government is not willing to exit the Euro; League’s Borghi shared the same view.  Alongside this, League's Economic Head said that Italy would solve most of its own problems if it had its own currency and added he would set the deficit at 3.1% if it wanted to confront the EU, whilst Deputy PM Salvini Italy is ready to ask for damages from Juncker and EU bureaucrats that are upsetting markets with their attacks on Italy. In later trade, Italian deputy PM Di Maio confirmed the outlines of the 2019 budget,  to include EUR 10bln for "Citizen's Income" and reiterating the 2.4% of GDP.

* TRADE: China are said to maintain communication with the US on talks, and said it was the US who proposed to delay the security meeting. Separately, White House Advisor Kudlow said the USMCA is sending a signal to China saying “we are acting as one”; he added the new NAFTA was negotiated in consultation with Democrats. On China, Kudlow noted the region has not made a serious enough effort at appeasing the US. Separately, US Senator Cornyn said that the Senate may lack votes to approve the USMCA, adding the earliest vote could occur is after November elections. Later, US President Trump said there seems to be great support for the trade deal in Congress whilst stating the US will have a great relationship with China.

* BREXIT: The Times reported overnight that PM May is to propose a ‘Grand Bargain’ to keep the UK within the EU customs union for goods after the transition period ends in December 2020 to break the deadlock in negotiations. This triggered responses from other leaders at the Tories Conference on Tuesday including UK Former Foreign Minister Boris Johnson who said to support UK PM May's original plan, likely referring to her Mansion House speech rather than her Chequers proposal. Elsewhere, after PM May noted the best way to solve the Irish border issue is based on the Chequers proposal, the DUP Leader Foster stated that there is no way they can accept different regulations in Northern Ireland and the rest of the country, not even as a backstop. UK Brexit Minister Raab said the UK is open to other deals adding he cannot let the EU off the hook for cavalier rebuff of Chequers plan, noting there is no such thing as pure independence. He said to expect a deal in time for Christmas, and urged to get an agreement in November otherwise will be too short on time for legislative time-frame. UK PM May later noted in the event of a no deal, WTO tariffs would come into effect.

*  FED: Fed’s Powell, speaking to the NABE, once again stuck to his upbeat message on the US economy, though remains cognizant of the risks facing the Fed. Powell said gradual rates are meant to balance risks and sees a "remarkably positive outlook" on inflation and employment; he stands ready to act "with authority" if inflation expectations drift from their target and does not expect significant inflation rise but is taking risk seriously. There was limited market reaction following his remarks. Fed’s Kaplan (Dove, non-voter) also spoke today where he said the Fed should be gradually moving rates towards the neutral stance, which he believes to be between 2.5% to 2.75%, and added it should assess once there, also mentioning that he is hopeful this can happen without inverting the yield curve. On the US economy, he noted that it is at or over full employment, GDP growth will be 3% this year whilst next year 2.5% as the fiscal stimulus fades; he further added that the debt-fuelled stimulus could turn into a headwind. He said he is happy with one more rate hike this year in December and the base case is two next year.

* ECB: ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) sees spillover effects from EM as limited; he added there can be no influence of fiscal policy on monetary policy.

* SPX 0.00% at 2930, NDX -0.22% at 7628, DJI +0.47% at 26775 SECTORS: Energy +0.12%, Materials +0.45%, Industrials +0.19%, Cons Discretionary -1.43%, Cons Staples +0.62%, Healthcare -0.09%, Financials +0.04%, Tech -0.01%, Telecoms +0.11%, Utilities +1.28%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Intel (INTC) was one of the day’s biggest movers after giving constructive forward guidance. Micron Technologies (MU) another gainer, alongside Lam Research (LRCX) and Applied Materials (AMAT), helping edge up the Philadelphia SE semiconductor index. PG&E (PCG) and other utilities also benefitted from a risk off sentiment as defensive sectors lead on the day. AMD (AMD) moved downwards against the semiconductor industry. Delta Air Lines (DAL) fell on a disappointing earnings view which had a knock on effect on the wider airline industry. Guggenheim downgraded Edwards Lifesciences (EW) making it the S&P 500’s biggest underperformer at the time of writing. Some China based names were also other big losers with NetEase (NTES) and Baidu (BIDU) dragging down the Nasdaq.   

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD 0.07 LOWER AT USD 75.23/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.18 LOWER AT USD 84.80/BBL. Ahead of this week’s inventory data, Brent is consolidating around $85/bbl after hitting highs not seen in four years on Monday. WTI, meanwhile, is hanging around the $75/bbl area. Russia on Tuesday reported production data with output rising by 150k BPD to a record 11.36mln BPD. Reports also suggested that the Saudi-Kuwait talks on shared oil projects are said to have stalled over the role of Chevron. On the brokerage front, Barclays raised its Q4 2018 Brent price forecast by $3 to $77/bbl. API are expected today after-market with crude seen +2.0mln, distillate -1.3mln, gasoline +1.3mln.

US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 4+ TICKS HIGHER AT 118-26. Action in the Treasury complex was dictated by developments on the 2019 budget over in Italy which led to a steeper yield curve as the Italy/German spread widened above 300bps. The complex dipped later in the session after Comcast launched a 12-part dollar bond to fund its USD 27bln acquisition of Sky; subsequently some flattening was seen across the yield curve. Most of the action was concentrated in the long end of the curve were yields were higher by c.3bps. 2s10 s and 2s30s were narrower by c.2bps at settlement.

* DXY: The index and broad Dollar have drifted down from best levels registered at the height of risk aversion on several factors including the ongoing US-China import tariff stand-off and budget barbs between the Italian Government and EU officials. The DXY climbed to 95.744 at one stage before easing back towards 95.500 as rival currencies clawed back some lost ground.

* EUR, GBP: EURUSD has recovered from just above 1.1500 having breached several downside chart levels from a peak of 1.1580 at one stage amid EU criticism over Italy’s budget. Similarly, Cable has rebounded from sub-1.2950 lows towards 1.2975 having accelerated losses through 1.3000 when stops were triggered on a break just above the big figure and the UK construction PMI missed consensus in contrast to Monday’s manufacturing headline print. However, unexpected backing for PM May from ex-Foreign Minister Johnson at the Conservative party conference, albeit on the Mansion House Brexit plan vs Chequers White Paper, helped the Pound regroup.

* AUD, NZD: Both managed to consolidate off worst levels and return towards 0.7200 and 0.6600 respectively after declines overnight on a neutral, hence not really supportive RBA and weak Q3 NZIER sentiment survey, while the Cad held within a relatively tight 1.2800-40 range vs its US counterpart.

* JPY, CHF:  buck the general trend with the former above 114.00 for the most part, but then sliding below that figure in later trade and the latter trading between 0.9855-30 parameters.

* EM: The Real was the star performer, or rather the exception to the norm and rallied through 4.0000 vs the USD to just over 3.9500 at best, with the catalyst coming in the form of latest pre-Brazilian election poll results from Ibope showing Bolsonaro extending his lead in the first round, to 31% from 27% previously, while Haddad stayed on 21%, and these two candidates seen even on 42% in a run-off.

subject: Canada light vehicle sales (September) -7.4%
Fed's Kaplan (dove, non-voter) says he is happy with one more rate hike this year in December, base case is two next year
content:
• says Fed no longer needs to be accommodative, but not reached judgement whether it should be restrictive, it will have to decide by next spring / summer

subject: Daily FX Wrap: tide turning after turbulent trade earlier on Tuesday
content:
DXY

The index and broad Dollar have drifted down from best levels registered at the height of risk aversion on several factors including the ongoing US-China import tariff stand-off and budget barbs between the Italian Government and EU officials. The DXY climbed to 95.744 at one stage before easing back towards 95.500 as rival currencies clawed back some lost ground.

G10   

The overall pattern remains the same, but the Greenbacks major counterparts regained a degree of composure to climb off session lows with the aid of some technical buying and less antagonistic headlines on the Italian fiscal and Brexit front. To recap, the session kicked off with pretty inflammatory remarks from Italy’s coalition Government, or at least the more belligerent members, and admonishments from Brussels for breaching the budget rules, but some investor angst was alleviated via reiterations that leaving the Eur is not on the agenda and a pledge not to exceed the 3% deficit ceiling beyond the 3 year period from 2019-2021 when 2.4% is targeted. Eur/Usd has subsequently recovered from just above 1.1500 having breached several downside chart levels from a peak of 1.1580 at one stage. Similarly, Cable has rebounded from sub-1.2950 lows towards 1.2975 having accelerated losses through 1.3000 when stops were triggered on a break just above the big figure and the UK construction PMI missed consensus in contrast to Monday’s manufacturing headline print. However, unexpected backing for PM May from ex-Foreign Minister Johnson at the Conservative party conference, albeit on the Mansion House Brexit plan vs Chequers White Paper, helped the Pound regroup.

The Aud and Nzd also managed to consolidate off worst levels and return towards 0.7200 and 0.6600 respectively after declines overnight on a neutral, hence not really supportive RBA and weak Q3 NZIER sentiment survey, while the Cad held within a relatively tight 1.2800-40 range vs its US counterpart.

The Jpy and Chf buck the general trend with the former above 114.00 for the most part and latter trading between 0.9855-30 parameters.

EM

The Real was the star performer, or rather the exception to the norm and rallied through 4.0000 vs the Usd to just over 3.9500 at best, with the catalyst coming in the form of latest pre-Brazilian election poll results from Ibope showing Bolsonaro extending his lead in the first round, to 31% from 27% previously, while Haddad stayed on 21%, and these two candidates seen even on 42% in a run-off.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • BTP yields hit 4 year highs and FTSE MIB underperforms after Borghi suggests Italy would be better off without the EUR
  • GBP the G10 laggard after poor PMI’s and negative Brexit commentary via the Tory conference
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US APIs and potential comments from BoE’s Haskel, Fed’s Quarles, ECB’s Villeroy, Fed’s Barkin, Powell, and BoE’s Haldane

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly lower as the upbeat sentiment from the USMCA deal seen on Wall St. faded away and trade concerns re-emerged after White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said a trade deal between US and China is not “imminent”.  ASX 200 (-0.8%) was dragged lower by the financial sector as Australia’s big four traded with losses in excess of a percent after the ACCC said they will examine the banks, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was cushioned on the back of currency effect. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.4%) underperformed as participants come back from the long weekend to downbeat trade comments from the US, meanwhile KOSPI (-1.2%) was also weighed by the sour sentiment as the index shrugged off optimistic industrial production data.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US will listen to China if they show willingness. (Fox)

China's narrowing interest rate spread with the US and declining current account surplus have led to some concerns regarding capital outflow. (FT)

China's Defense Ministry said they resolutely opposed the US "freedom of navigation" adding it's a threat to sovereignty which China will take necessary measures to defend. (Newswires)

BoJ’s September Tankan Corporate Price Expectation Survey stated Japanese firms sees Y/Y inflation at 0.8% (Prev. 0.9%); 3yr and 5yr expectations unchanged at 1.1%. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May is preparing to limit Britain's ability to strike free-trade deals after Brexit in a significant concession to the EU aimed at breaking the deadlock in negotiations. She is to propose “Grand Bargain” to keep Britain tied to European customs rules on goods after transition period ends in December 2020. Northern Irish DUP MP stated that UK border proposals reported in the Times had not been presented to their party and they will not comment on it; will continue to support May. The DUP leader added they are speaking to the UK government regarding Irish border proposals and they need to see text before decisions can be made. (The Times/Newswires)

UK Immigration Minister Nokes believes the government seeks a post-Brexit immigration system that treats all nations equally but gives ministers the flexibility to tailor rules for countries negotiating trade deals. (Newswires)

EU diplomats have rejected UK PM May’s conference pitch that Brussels must move first to break the deadlock over negotiations. (Guardian)

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson told senior conservatives that he would delay Brexit by at least six months if he became PM. (Newswires) This comes ahead of Johnson’s speech today at the Conservative Party Conference which many see as essentially his pitch to succeed PM May. (FT)

Senior Brexiteers believe they’ve got just two weeks left to kill off Chequers, according to sources familiar with their discussions (Buzzfeed)

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI Sep 52.1 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.9)

League's Economic Head said that Italy would solve most of its own problems if it had its own currency and adds that Italy would set the deficit at 3.1% if it wanted to confront the EU. Italian Government Source said PM Conte is to meet key ministers at 6:00PM BST over the budget targets. Italian Deputy PM DI Maio said they will not change the 2.4% debt/GDP target, and that the 2019-21 budget will be completed today, adding that the Italian Government is not willing to exit the Euro or the EU. (Newswires)

EU's Dombrovskis stated that the EU are open to dialogue with Italian authorities regarding the budget. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker stated that the EU want a deal on Brexit but are united on the Irish border issue. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korean government spokesperson said US is still trying to subdue the country via sanctions, while he reiterated that North Korea is taking substantial steps to implement the joint statement. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have started the day in the red. This comes after suggestions from Italian Lawmaker Borghi hinting that the country would be better off leaving the Euro. Despite an intention to leave the Euro later denied by the Deputy PM, Italian assets are seeing significant losses, with Italian Bank stocks down over 2%, and the FTSE MIB once again at the bottom of the index pile. 

The financial sector is lagging its peers due to the weakness in Italian banks, with the energy sector outperforming off the back of oil prices hitting 4 year highs.

The FTSE is the outperforming bourse off the back of a Brexit-hit GBP, but is trading in negative territory. The index is being pressured by a collapse in Royal Mail shares after a guidance cut in Monday’s trade, with the co. extending losses in the European morning. The stock is now at the foot of the Stoxx 600 and has hit the lowest level in its lifetime.

FX

EUR - The single currency is not the biggest G10 loser vs a generally firm USD, as the DXY rebounds to just over 95.700 amidst broad Dollar gains vs rivals, bar the safer-havens, but has been centre stage since Tuesday’s EU ‘open’ following more Italian budget headlines underlying a defiant stance on the 2019 deficit. Indeed, members of the coalition insist that the proposed 2.4% target is fixed ahead of another budget meeting and presentation to parliament on Wednesday, while the League party’s Borghi contends that the Government would have set the bar even higher at 3.1% if it really wanted to take on the EU, adding that the country’s fiscal problems could be solved if it was not in the Eur club. Eur/Usd has now fallen below a 50% fib (1.1558) through a daily support level (1.1529) and September’s low (1.1526) to trip stops under 1.1525 and 1.1520 ahead of a final downside technical target (1.1509) before 1.1500.

GBP - Another major underperformer amidst a raft of Brexit commentary from the Tory conference, but accelerating to the downside once stops were tripped on a break of 1.3012 in Cable and that pairing failed to keep hold of the 1.3000 handle. However, the Pound was also undermined by a weaker than forecast headline UK construction PMI and is currently eyeing bids ahead of 1.2950.

AUD/NZD - Already on the backfoot during overnight trade, partly due to ongoing US-China trade concerns, as President Trump stated that now is not the time to talk, but for the Aud also as RBA policy guidance remained neutral, the antipodean Dollars are extending losses and deeply through big figures that had been providing some traction (0.7200 and 0.6600 respectively). Aud now only just holding above 0.7150 and the Kiwi 0.6575 ahead of the latest GDT auction.

CAD - The Greenback’s resurgence has eroded more USMCA-inspired Loonie (and Peso) gains, with Usd/Cad rebounding a bit further above 1.2800 having held above key/strong technical support yesterday.

JPY/CHF - Relatively resilient against the overall Dollar bid, with Usd/Jpy retreating from 114.00+ peaks on a broad downturn in risk sentiment, but still technically bullish while not seriously threatening 113.50 and a series of chart supports below, while the Franc has rebounded to circa 0.9835 and 1.1325 vs the Eur.

EM - Losses across the board vs the Usd as recent recovery momentum stalls and reverses on largely negative external factors rather than anything new detrimental in the region. Indeed, even the Rub is weaker around 65.5000 and not deriving any support/impetus from the latest spike in oil prices.

FIXED INCOME

Another BTP boost for the 10 year German benchmark as Italian Government officials continue to stand rigidly by their fiscal guns and rail against the EU establishment with claims about Germany and France wanting the coalition to collapse, while one prominent League party member also suggests that the country would be able to solve its budget issues if it resorted to the Lira. Bunds gapped up to 159.06 off the Eurex open and advanced to 159.35 vs 158.77 at yesterday’s close before topping out, while their Italian counterparts have been as much as 152 ticks below parity at 121.20, but are now trying to regroup.  

COMMODITIES

In the oil market, WTI is hanging around the USD 75.40/BBL level and unchanged for the day after the benchmark hit four-year-long highs in early European trade.

Production figures were released from Russia for September, who said this stood at 11.36mln BPD vs. 11.21mln BPD in August.

In the metals sector, gold is marginally in the green as the yellow metal has caught a safe-haven bid in the Italy driven risk-off tone. Copper prices have fallen for the second straight session after slowing growth in the Chinese manufacturing sector has continued to stoke concerns over demand for the construction material.

content: Still lagging behind their core Eurozone peers on looser links or inverse correlations to Italian assets, but Gilts are tracking Bunds higher again as BTPs reverse sharply (through 121.00 at one stage) amidst latest staunch rhetoric from Rome in defence of 2019 budget proposals. The 10 year UK bond is back above 121.00 and close to the apex of a 121.00-43 range, while Bunds have now rallied through successive chart resistance levels, including last Friday’s Eurex session high and a 50% Fib on their way to 159.78 (+101 ticks vs +51 ticks for Gilts at best). The Short Sterling strip is also bid and the curve flatter between flat and 3 ticks ahead, as attention returns to Tuesday’s UK agenda (for a while at least) that continues with the construction PMI after Nationwide house prices and before BoE speakers Haldane and Haskell.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

2nd October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly lower as the upbeat sentiment from the USMCA deal seen on Wall St. faded away and trade concerns re-emerged after White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said a trade deal between US and China is not “imminent”.  ASX 200 (-0.8%) was dragged lower by the financial sector as Australia’s big four traded with losses in excess of a percent after the ACCC said they will examine the banks, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was cushioned on the back of currency effect. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.4%) underperformed as participants come back from the long weekend to downbeat trade comments from the US, meanwhile KOSPI (-0.8%) was also weighed by the sour sentiment as the index shrugged off optimistic industrial production data.

FTSE

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Schroders have joined calls for the co. to stop its planned HQ move from London to the Netherlands. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. have finalised the sale of their downstream operations to Raizen for USD 916mln in cash. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Sports Direct International (SPD LN) – Ex-directors and senior management of House of Fraser have been fired by the co. as investors call for investigations into the collapse of the department store. (Guardian)

Berkeley (BKG LN) – The co.’s shares were hit on Monday off the back of reports that UK PM May was planning to announce a stamp duty of up to 3% for foreign buyers, with the intention of stopping large-scale purchases of property. (Telegraph)

Whitbread (WTB LN) – The co. has said it will restructure the management at its Premier Inn hotel chain, removing the operations manager post at over 800 hotels. (Newswires)

Vedanta Resources (VED LN) – Shareholders in the co have supported delisting shares in London as the co. has faced protests and legal action over their controversial copper smelter in Tamil Nadu. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

POLYMETAL (POLY LN) UPGRADED TO HOLD AT JEFFERIES

ROYAL MAIL (RMG LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

UNILEVER (ULVR LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT JEFFERIES

DAX

German Auto Names – German coalition leaders agreed a plan to cut pollution whilst avoiding driving bans on Tuesday morning. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The client side of Deutsche Bank’s capital markets business rates, forex and equity have been combined into a global unit. Elsewhere, a planned IPO has been deferred because of leadership changes and market conditions for Australia’s Latitude Financial, which is partially owned by Deutsche Bank.  (Handelsblatt/Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – The co. is reportedly making contingency plans for all Brexit scenarios including a “hard complicated Brexit”. (Sky)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – Co. now expect to leave the DAX after their recent split. (FAZ)

BROKER MOVES

SIEMENS (SIE GY) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT HSBC

UNIPER (UNO1 GY) REITERATED UNDERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks traded mostly lower as the upbeat sentiment from the USMCA deal seen on Wall St. faded away
  • UK PM May is preparing to limit Britain's ability to strike free-trade deals after Brexit in a significant concession to the EU aimed at breaking the deadlock in negotiations
  • The RBA stood pat on rates as expected and stated that low interest rates are supporting the economy, while business conditions and the outlook for the labour market remain positive
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US APIs and potential comments from BoE’s Haskel, Fed’s Quarles, ECB’s Villeroy, Fed’s Barkin, Powell, and BoE’s Haldane

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded mostly lower as the upbeat sentiment from the USMCA deal seen on Wall St. faded away and trade concerns re-emerged after White House Economic Advisor Kudlow said a trade deal between US and China is not “imminent”.  ASX 200 (-0.8%) was dragged lower by the financial sector as Australia’s big four traded with losses in excess of a percent after the ACCC said they will examine the banks, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was cushioned on the back of currency effect. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.4%) underperformed as participants come back from the long weekend to downbeat trade comments from the US, meanwhile KOSPI (-0.8%) was also weighed by the sour sentiment as the index shrugged off optimistic industrial production data.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US will listen to China if they show willingness. (Fox)

China's narrowing interest rate spread with the US and declining current account surplus have led to some concerns regarding capital outflow. (FT)

China's Defense Ministry said they resolutely opposed the US "freedom of navigation" adding it's a threat to sovereignty which China will take necessary measures to defend. (Newswires)

BoJ’s September Tankan Corporate Price Expectation Survey stated Japanese firms sees Y/Y inflation at 0.8% (Prev. 0.9%); 3yr and 5yr expectations unchanged at 1.1%. (Newswires)


UK

UK PM May is preparing to limit Britain's ability to strike free-trade deals after Brexit in a significant concession to the EU aimed at breaking the deadlock in negotiations. She is to propose “Grand Bargain” to keep Britain tied to European customs rules on goods after transition period ends in December 2020. (The Times)

UK Immigration Minister Nokes believes the government seeks a post-Brexit immigration system that treats all nations equally but gives ministers the flexibility to tailor rules for countries negotiating trade deals. (Newswires)

UK lawmaker and Brexit hardliner Rees-Mogg said changing a leadership usually causes more problems than it solves, it's prudent to back PM May. (Newswires)

EU diplomats have rejected UK PM May’s conference pitch that Brussels must move first to break the deadlock over negotiations. (Guardian)

UK Chancellor Hammond said if WTO regulations are implemented we will have to have border checks, while he added we need a very very gradual process of re-balancing our trade with the EU. (Newswires)

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson told senior conservatives that he would delay Brexit by at least six months if he became PM. (Newswires) This comes ahead of Johnson’s speech today at the Conservative Party Conference which many see as essentially his pitch to succeed PM May. (FT)

EU

EU Commission President Juncker, on Italy's 2019 budget proposal, said “we are in talks” and he added “if they want further special treatment it would end the Euro.” (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Williams (Neutral, Voter) said as we move towards a more normal conduct of policy, we shouldn't rest easy and think we won’t run into future challenges. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (Hawkish, Non-voter) said FOMC should continue on its current pace of raising rates, and the further the US gets below full employment the higher the risk of inflation increasing. He said the continued growth and tighter labour markets will likely lead to imbalances including but not limited to inflation, while strong growth is expected to continue for now, though trade and emerging markets problems pose risks. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Dove, Non-voter) said so far tax cuts have not boosted business spending outside of the oil sector, we are probably not at full employment.

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) said it is now or never to build economic union. (Newswires)

FX

Tentative trade in FX markets with the greenback little changed and major pairs trading flat. NZD initially saw some downside following a weaker Q3 business confidence, while AUD/USD was nudged higher by 10 pips as the RBA stood pat on rates as expected and stated that low interest rates are supporting the economy, while business conditions and the outlook for the labour market remain positive. Elsewhere, JPY initially attempted to crawl further from the 114.00 level against the dollar, however remained in close proximity to the figure.

RBA maintained the Cash Rate at the record low 1.50% for a 23rd straight meeting. The central bank reiterated low rates are supporting the economy and progress on unemployment and inflation is expected to be gradual, the statement added that 2018 and 2019 GDP growth is to average slightly above 3%. The RBA stated business conditions and the outlook for the labour market remains positive, however the drought has led to difficulties in the farming sector.

GEOPOLITICS

North Korean government spokesperson said US is still trying to subdue the country via sanctions, while he reiterated that North Korea is taking substantial steps to implement the joint statement. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded little changed as WTI and Brent hovered around four-year highs at USD 75.50/bbl and USD 85.00/bbl respectively, while traders continue to pin the rally in prices on oil-related Iranian sanctions coming into effect in just over a month. Elsewhere, gold mirrored the miniscule dollar moves while copper underperformed as demand concerns re-surfaced amid less optimistic trade comments from the US.

US

The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday, falling after overnight news of a free trade deal in principle between US, Mexico and Canada. A slight easing in Italian budget tensions was also cited for the bund sell-off in early European trade, which Tsys sympathised with. 2-year yields edging up slightly, while longer-dated yields rose by as much as c.4bps at settlement. Major curve spreads also widened modestly (2s5s up 0.3bps, 2s30s wider by around 2.5bps, struggling to maintain ground above their 50DMAs, technicians observed). US T-note futures (Z8) settles 3+ ticks lower at 118-21+.

US President Trump said he expects to sign the new USMCA deal by the end of November. US White House Advisor Navarro mentioned November 30th, while Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo stated that the new USMCA could be signed by the three Presidents at the G20 on November 29th. Guajardo also said that the new US-Mexico-Canada trade deal could take effect from the second half of 2019. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said the US has expressed willingness to discuss steel and aluminium tariffs. In related news, US President Trump said steel and aluminium tariffs will remain on Canada and Mexico unless they can do something like quotas, while USTR Ligthizer and US Commerce Secretary Ross said there is no deadline for resolving metals tariff dispute. (Newswires)
